column1: Annapolis (pronunciation ; ) is the capital of the U.S. state of Maryland
column2: as well as the county seat of Anne Arundel County. Situated on the Chesapeake Bay at the mouth of the Severn River
column3: 25 miles (40 km) south of Baltimore and about 30 miles (50 km) east of Washington
column5: Annapolis is part of the Baltimore–Washington metropolitan area. Its population was measured at 38

column1: This city served as the seat of the Confederation Congress (former Second Continental Congress) and temporary national capital of the United States in 1783–1784. At that time
column2: General George Washington came before the body convened in the new Maryland State House and resigned his commission as commander of the Continental Army. A month later
column3: the Congress ratified the Treaty of Paris of 1783
column5: with Great Britain recognizing the independence of the United States.

column1: The city and state capitol was also the site of the 1786 Annapolis Convention
column2: which issued a call to the states to send delegates for the Constitutional Convention to be held the following year in Philadelphia. Over 220 years later
column3: the Annapolis Peace Conference was held in 2007. Annapolis is the home of St. John's College
column4: founded 1696; the United States Naval Academy
column6: is adjacent to the city limits.

column1: A settlement in the Province of Maryland named "Providence" was founded on the north shore of the Severn River on the middle Western Shore of the Chesapeake Bay in 1649 by Puritan exiles from the Province/Dominion of Virginia led by third Proprietary Governor William Stone (1603–1660). The settlers later moved to a better-protected harbor on the south shore. The settlement on the south shore was initially named "Town at Proctor's
column3: and later Anne Arundel's Towne" (after Lady Ann Arundell (1616–1649)
column7: after the Third English Civil War
column8: Parliamentary forces assumed control of the Maryland colony and Stone went into exile further south across the Potomac River in Virginia. Per orders from Charles Calvert
column10: Stone returned the following spring at the head of a Cavalier royalist force
column11: loyal to the King of England.  On March 25
column13: in what is known as the Battle of the Severn (first colonial naval battle in North America)
column16: and replaced by Lt. Gen. Josias Fendall (1628–1687) as fifth Proprietary Governor. Fendall governed Maryland during the latter half of the Commonwealth period in England. In 1660
column17: he was replaced by Phillip Calvert (1626–1682) as fifth/sixth Governor of Maryland
column18: after the restoration of Charles II (1630–1685) as King in England.

column2: soon after the overthrow of the Catholic government of second Royal Governor Thomas Lawrence (1645–1714)
column3: then third Royal Governor Francis Nicholson (1655-1727/28
column5: moved the capital of the royal colony
column7: to Anne Arundel's Towne and renamed the town Annapolis after Princess Anne of Denmark and Norway
column8: soon to be the Queen Anne of Great Britain (1665–1714
column9: reigned 1702–1714). Annapolis was incorporated as a city in 1708. Colonel John Seymour
column10: the Governor of Maryland wrote Queen Anne on March 16
column12: with qualifications for municipal officials and provisions for fairs and market days for the town.17th-century Annapolis was little more than a village
column13: but it grew rapidly for most of the 18th century until the American Revolutionary War as a political and administrative capital
column15: and a major center of the Atlantic slave trade. The Maryland Gazette
column16: which became an important weekly journal
column17: was founded there by Jonas Green in 1745; in 1769 a theatre was opened; during this period also the commerce was considerable
column20: was made a port of entry in 1780. Water trades such as oyster-packing
column21: boatbuilding and sailmaking became the city's chief industries. Annapolis is home to a large number of recreational boats that have largely replaced the seafood industry in the city.

column1: Dr. Alexander Hamilton (1712–1756) was a Scottish-born doctor and writer who lived and worked in Annapolis.  Leo Lemay says his 1744 travel diary Gentleman's Progress: The Itinerarium of Dr. Alexander Hamilton is "the best single portrait of men and manners
column3: of the wide range of society and scenery in colonial America."Annapolis became the temporary capital of the United States after the signing of the Treaty of Paris in 1783. Congress was in session in the state house from November 26
column7: and it was in Annapolis on December 23
column9: that General Washington resigned his commission as commander-in-chief of the Continental Army.For the 1783 Congress
column10: the Governor of Maryland commissioned John Shaw
column12: to create an American flag. The flag is slightly different from other designs of the time. The blue field extends over the entire height of the hoist. Shaw created two versions of the flag: one which started with a red stripe and another that started with a white one.In 1786
column13: delegates from all states of the Union were invited to meet in Annapolis to consider measures for the better regulation of commerce. Delegates from only five states—New York
column18: known afterward as the "Annapolis Convention." Without proceeding to the business for which they had met
column19: the delegates passed a resolution calling for another convention to meet at Philadelphia in the following year to amend the Articles of Confederation. The Philadelphia convention drafted and approved the Constitution of the United States

column3: the midshipmen of the Naval Academy relocated their base in Annapolis and were temporarily housed in Newport
column6: the first of three camps that were built for holding paroled soldiers was created on the campus of St. John's College. The second location of Camp Parole would house over 20
column7: 000 and would be located where Forest Drive is currently. The third and final location was finished in late 1863 and would be placed near the Elkridge Railroad
column8: as to make transportation of soldiers and resources easier before and allowing the camp to grow to its highest numbers. This area just west of the city is still referred to as Parole. The soldiers who did not survive were buried in the Annapolis National Cemetery.

column3: Henry Davis was lynched in the city. He was suspected of assaulting a local woman. Nobody was ever tried for the crime.

column2: shipyards in Annapolis built a number of PT Boats
column3: and military vessels such as minesweepers and patrol boats were built in Annapolis during the Korean and Vietnam wars. It was at Annapolis in July 1940 that Grand Duchess Charlotte of Luxembourg arrived in exile during World War II.

column2: the Navy Marine Corps Memorial Stadium in Annapolis hosted soccer games as part of the XXIII Olympiad.

column3: Hurricane Isabel created the largest storm surge known in Annapolis's history
column4: cresting at 7.58 feet (2.31 m). Much of downtown Annapolis was flooded and many businesses and homes in outlying areas were damaged. The previous record was 6.35 feet (1.94 m) during a hurricane in 1933
column5: and 5.5 feet (1.7 m) during Hurricane Hazel in 1954. Downtown Annapolis has high-tide "sunny day" flooding. A Stanford University study found that this resulted in 3
column7: 000 in lost revenue for local business in 2017.From mid-2007 through December 2008
column8: the city celebrated the 300th anniversary of its 1708 Royal Charter
column9: which established democratic self-governance. The many cultural events of this celebration were organized by Annapolis Charter 300.

column1: Annapolis was home of the Anne Arundel County Battle of the Bands
column2: which was held at Maryland Hall from 1999–2015. The event was a competition between musical groups from each high school in the county; it raised over $100

column7: killing five journalists and injuring two more. The perpetrator of the shooting was Jarrod Ramos.

column1: As announced by United States Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice

column3: with the participation of Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Olmert

column1: The Maryland State House is the oldest in continuous legislative use in the United States. Construction started in 1772
column2: and the Maryland legislature first met there in 1779. It is topped by the largest wooden dome built without nails in the country. The Maryland State House housed the workings of the United States government from November 26
column6: and the Treaty of Paris was ratified there on January 14
column8: so Annapolis became the first peacetime capital of the U.S.It was in the Maryland State House that George Washington famously resigned his commission before the Continental Congress on December 23

column1: The United States Naval Academy was founded in 1845 on the site of Fort Severn
column2: and now occupies an area of land reclaimed from the Severn River next to the Chesapeake Bay. The Annapolis area was the home of a VLF-transmitter called NSS Annapolis
column3: which was used by the United States Navy to communicate with its Atlantic submarine fleet. Students that attend the Naval Academy are enrolled in school for four years with a following five year commitment to serving in the Marine Corps or Navy. There is a typical average of around 4

column1: St. John's College is a non-sectarian private college that was once supported by the state. It was opened in 1789 as the successor of King William's School
column2: which was founded by an act of the Maryland legislature in 1696 and was opened in 1701. Its principal building
column3: McDowell Hall
column4: was originally to be the governor's mansion; although £4
column5: 000 was appropriated to build it in 1742
column6: it was not completed until after the War of Independence.St. John's has a second campus in Santa Fe
column7: New Mexico. Students are able to choose between the two campuses and switch at any point in their education. The curriculum of St. John's relies heavily on the use of literature with their Great Books Curriculum
column8: which focuses on texts of Western Civilization. Each year
column9: students are required to participate in a seminar-style course to discuss the assigned works. This program has been highlighted as one that is unique to St. John's and requires the students to become well-versed through reading about political science

column1: Annapolis has a thriving community theater scene which includes two venues in the historic district.

column2: Colonial Players produces approximately six shows a year in its 180-seat theater. A Christmas Carol has been a seasonal tradition in Annapolis since it opened at the Colonial Players theater in 1981. Based on the play by Charles Dickens
column3: the 90-minute production by the Colonial Players is an original musical adaptation
column4: with play and lyrics by Richard Wade and music by Dick Gessner. Colonial Players
column5: Inc. is a nonprofit organization founded in 1949. Its first production
column7: was performed in 1949 at the Annapolis Recreation Center on Compromise Street. In 1955
column8: the organization moved to its venue in a former automotive repair shop on East Street.During the warmer months
column9: Annapolis Summer Garden Theatre presents three shows on its outdoor stage
column10: which is visible from the City Dock. A nonprofit organization
column11: Annapolis Summer Garden Theatre has been providing "theatre under the stars" since 1966
column12: when it performed You Can't Take It with You and Brigadoon at Carvel Hall Hotel. It began leasing its site at 143 Compromise Street
column13: the former location of the Shaw Blacksmith Shop
column15: and became owner of the property in 1990.The Naval Academy Masqueraders

column1: Annapolis City Dock lies at the foot of Main Street that slopes down from Church Circle and St. Anne's Church. The dock is now a narrow waterway from Spa Creek
column2: once named Carrol's Creek with the dock area called Dock Cove
column3: into the heart of the lower town. At the head of the dock is a small park with the Kunta Kinte-Alex Haley Memorial with the Market House and a traffic circle in an expanse of asphalt surrounded by historic buildings. The Market House
column5: stands in a vicinity occupied by similar market houses dating to 1730 when the city market was moved from the State House area to the head of the dock. The dock itself is now used largely by recreational vessels rather than the commercial boats and boats of Chesapeake Bay watermen selling catches. The dock and surroundings are part of the Colonial Annapolis National Historic Landmark (NHL) District.The Kunta Kinte-Alex Haley memorial
column6: located in a park at the head of Annapolis City Dock
column7: commemorates the arrival point of Alex Haley's African ancestor
column8: Kunta Kinte
column9: whose story is related in Haley's book Roots. A sculpture group at the memorial site portrays Alex Haley seated
column10: reading from a book to three children. The final phase of the memorial's construction was completed in 2002.The Paca House and Garden encompasses an 18th-century Georgian mansion constructed by William Paca
column11: a signer of the Declaration of Independence. The property includes a terraced garden that has been restored to its colonial-era design.Annapolis often serves as the end point for the 3
column12: 000-mile annual transcontinental Race Across America bicycle race.

column4: 454 men who gave their lives in the war. Directly behind the memorial are both the Maryland
column6: and a star shaped column with a seven sided base to represent Maryland being the seventh state in the Union.

column1: Annapolis is governed via the weak mayor system. The city council consists of eight aldermen who are elected from single member wards. The mayor is elected directly in a citywide vote.  Since 2008
column2: several aldermen have introduced unsuccessful charter amendments to institute a council-manager system
column3: a move opposed by both Democratic mayor Joshua J. Cohen and his Republican successor Mike Pantelides.

No major highways enter the city limits of Annapolis. However
column3: Interstate 595/U.S. Route 50/U.S. Route 301 traverses the region on an east–west route
column4: connecting the Annapolis area to Washington
column6: and the Eastern Shore of Maryland. Interstate 97 interchanges with I-595/US 50/US 301 a few miles west of Annapolis and provides the most direct link to Baltimore. Maryland Route 2 also passes just outside the city limits and is the best connection to Southern Maryland
column7: while also providing an alternate route to Baltimore.

column1: The most prominent roads directly accessing the city include Maryland Route 70

column3: and Maryland Route 665
column4: which does likewise for the southwestern portions of the city. Other state highways serving Annapolis include Maryland Route 181
column7: Maryland Route 435

column1: The Annapolis Department of Transportation (ADOT) provides bus service with eight routes
column2: collectively branded Annapolis Transit. The system serves the city with recreational areas
column3: shopping centers
column5: and employment hubs. ADOT also offers transportation for the elderly and persons with disabilities. Several Maryland Transit Administration commuter buses also allow for access to Baltimore or Washington

column1: Annapolis is the only capital city in America east of the Mississippi River without rail transport of any sort. From 1840 to 1968
column2: Annapolis was connected to the outside world by railroad. The Washington
column3: Baltimore and Annapolis Railroad (WB&A) operated two electrified interurban lines that brought passengers into the city from both the South and the North. The southern route ran down King George Street and Main Street
column5: while the northern route entered town via Glen Burnie. In 1935
column6: the WB&A went bankrupt due to the effects of the Great Depression and suspended service along its southern route
column7: while the newly created Baltimore and Annapolis Railroad (B&A) retained service on the northern route. Steam trains of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad also occasionally operated over the line to Annapolis
column8: primarily for special Naval Academy movements. Passenger rail service on the B&A was eventually discontinued in 1950; freight service ceased in 1968 after the dilapidated trestle crossing the Severn River was condemned. The tracks were eventually dismantled in 1976.
